Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"
Research management developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary/secondary/diverse sources, collecting & using data, applying research methods, applying ethics
"
How this is developed:
""

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
"
Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
"
How this is developed:
"Critical thinking & creativity will be developed by appraisal of experimental data and information from the scientific literature"

Skill/Other Attribute 3:
"
Problem solving skills
"
How this is developed:
"Problem solving will be developed in experimental design and trouble-shooting"

Skill/Other Attribute 4:
"
Communication skills
"
How this is developed:
""
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are: To provide an opportunity to extensively research a specific topic (or topics) To afford insights into contemporary scientific methods and debate To encourage the development of independent working and critical appraisal skills
Marketing Module Synopsis
Pharmacology ResearchProjects (PHAR660) is a 30 credit module that runs throughout both semesters in Year 3. The module is designed to provide students with experience in conducting research projects, poster presentations, oral presentations and in preparing project reports and dissertations.
Outline Syllabus
PHAR660 comprises two main components; an experimental research project and a library-based dissertation. SIn Semester 1, students will do the library project. In Semester 2, students will undertake the experimental-research project Students will be allocated a different supervisor for their experimental and library projects. All students will receive training in the use of Endnote software in week 1, Semester 1. All students will also attend a tutorial on academic integrity in week 1. Students will work on the library project from 9am to 5pm on Tues to Thurs each week during weeks 2 to 6 (inclusive) of Semester 1. Students are permitted to work on their library project at other times during those weeks, on the understanding that lectures and coursework take priority at other times.Students will give a 15 minute presentation (10-11 mins talk, 3-4 mins questions; 8-12 slides) using Microsoft PowerPoint. Presentations will be held over two or more sessions during week 10 of Semester 1 (Group B) or Semester 2 (Group A) in front of an audience of fellow students and academic staff (who will act as markers).Students will submit an electronic copy of their final library dissertation by the end of week 11 of Semester 1 . In semester 2 students will undertake 2-3 days of Lab Skills training in week 1 o Students will work on the lab project from 9am to 5pm on Tues to Thurs each week during weeks 2 to 7 (inclusive) of Semester 2 . Students are permitted to undertake lab work on one additional day (Mon or Fri) of those weeks, on the understanding that lectures take priority on additional days.. In the event of COVID restrictions limiting student access to the research laboratories contingency plans have been designed. If lab space is limited students will work in small groups, whereby each performs 1 – 2 weeks of laboratory work which will then be collated with the collective data of the group to form the final data set for analysis and the basis of their report. If no lab access is possible students will be assigned a dry experimental. These can take the form of computational, modelling, bioinformatic analysis or database analysis projects and will be managed by the supervisor in the same way as the lboratory projects. Students will produce and present an A0 poster in week 10 of Semester 2 . Posters will be presented in a group session and students will discuss their poster content with and answer related questions from academic staff (who will act as markers). In case of COVID restrictions this can be done via Teams. Students will submit an electronic copy of their final laboratory project report by the end of week 11 of Semester 2
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Tutorial Description: One to one supervision sessions, delivered via Teams or face-to face if COVID restrictions allow to discuss progress of lab projects, direction and content of library dissertation, plus other supporting face-to-face sessions. Attendance Recorded: No.
Notes: 6 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of lab projects; 5 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of library projects; 1 x 2 hour session on Endnote, delivered via synchronous, online Teams workshop; 1 x 1 hour session on scientific literature analysis delivered in small groups face-to-face or via Teams in case of COVID restrictions; 1 x 1 hour session on academic integrity.

Teaching Method 2 - Laboratory Work
Description: Active participation in laboratory research in pursuit of the lab-project component of PHAR660, in the case of COVID restrictions “dry” experimental projects will be supervised by twice weekly one-to-one supervisor sessions within the 6-week research session.
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: 6 weeks x 3.5 days of project work plus 1 day of Lab Skills Unscheduled Directed Student Hours (time spent away from the timetabled sessions but directed by the teaching staff): 140

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Library dissertation not anonymously marked. Dissertation marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Oral presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Poster presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Laboratory project report not anonymously marked. Report marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To undertake academic research in an efficient, safe and responsible manner
 LO2 ​To search, index and evaluate the scientific literature for the purposes of pharmacological study
 LO3 ​To plan, perform and record progress of studies that explore specific scientific questions and hypotheses
 LO4 ​To analyse and evaluate scientific data and information and draw informed conclusions
 LO5 ​To prepare written reports that effectively communicate scientific findings to the reader
 LO6 ​To prepare and deliver oral and poster presentations that effectively communicate scientific findings to the respective audience(s)
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Research management developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary/secondary/diverse sources, collecting &amp; using data, applying research methods, applying ethics
 S2 ​Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S3 ​​Problem solving skills
 S4 ​​Communication skills

Teaching Method 1 - Tutorial Description: One to one supervision sessions, delivered via Teams or face-to face if COVID restrictions allow to discuss progress of lab projects, direction and content of library dissertation, plus other supporting face-to-face sessions. Attendance Recorded: No.
Notes: 6 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of lab projects; 5 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of library projects; 1 x 2 hour session on Endnote, delivered via synchronous, online Teams workshop; 1 x 1 hour session on scientific literature analysis delivered in small groups face-to-face or via Teams in case of COVID restrictions; 1 x 1 hour session on academic integrity.

Teaching Method 2 - Laboratory Work
Description: Active participation in laboratory research in pursuit of the lab-project component of PHAR660, in the case of COVID restrictions “dry” experimental projects will be supervised by twice weekly one-to-one supervisor sessions within the 6-week research session.
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: 6 weeks x 3.5 days of project work plus 1 day of Lab Skills Unscheduled Directed Student Hours (time spent away from the timetabled sessions but directed by the teaching staff): 140

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Library dissertation not anonymously marked. Dissertation marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Oral presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Poster presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Laboratory project report not anonymously marked. Report marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Educational Aims
The aims of this module are: To provide an opportunity to extensively research a specific topic (or topics) To afford insights into contemporary scientific methods and debate To encourage the development of independent working and critical appraisal skills
Marketing Module Synopsis
Pharmacology ResearchProjects (PHAR660) is a 30 credit module that runs throughout both semesters in Year 3. The module is designed to provide students with experience in conducting research projects, poster presentations, oral presentations and in preparing project reports and dissertations.
Outline Syllabus
PHAR660 comprises two main components; an experimental research project and a library-based dissertation. SIn Semester 1, students will do the library project. In Semester 2, students will undertake the experimental-research project Students will be allocated a different supervisor for their experimental and library projects. All students will receive training in the use of Endnote software in week 1, Semester 1. All students will also attend a tutorial on academic integrity in week 1. Students will work on the library project from 9am to 5pm on Tues to Thurs each week during weeks 2 to 6 (inclusive) of Semester 1. Students are permitted to work on their library project at other times during those weeks, on the understanding that lectures and coursework take priority at other times.Students will give a 15 minute presentation (10-11 mins talk, 3-4 mins questions; 8-12 slides) using Microsoft PowerPoint. Presentations will be held over two or more sessions during week 10 of Semester 1 (Group B) or Semester 2 (Group A) in front of an audience of fellow students and academic staff (who will act as markers).Students will submit an electronic copy of their final library dissertation by the end of week 11 of Semester 1 . In semester 2 students will undertake 2-3 days of Lab Skills training in week 1 o Students will work on the lab project from 9am to 5pm on Tues to Thurs each week during weeks 2 to 7 (inclusive) of Semester 2 . Students are permitted to undertake lab work on one additional day (Mon or Fri) of those weeks, on the understanding that lectures take priority on additional days.. In the event of COVID restrictions limiting student access to the research laboratories contingency plans have been designed. If lab space is limited students will work in small groups, whereby each performs 1 – 2 weeks of laboratory work which will then be collated with the collective data of the group to form the final data set for analysis and the basis of their report. If no lab access is possible students will be assigned a dry experimental. These can take the form of computational, modelling, bioinformatic analysis or database analysis projects and will be managed by the supervisor in the same way as the lboratory projects. Students will produce and present an A0 poster in week 10 of Semester 2 . Posters will be presented in a group session and students will discuss their poster content with and answer related questions from academic staff (who will act as markers). In case of COVID restrictions this can be done via Teams. Students will submit an electronic copy of their final laboratory project report by the end of week 11 of Semester 2
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Tutorial Description: One to one supervision sessions, delivered via Teams or face-to face if COVID restrictions allow to discuss progress of lab projects, direction and content of library dissertation, plus other supporting face-to-face sessions. Attendance Recorded: No.
Notes: 6 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of lab projects; 5 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of library projects; 1 x 2 hour session on Endnote, delivered via synchronous, online Teams workshop; 1 x 1 hour session on scientific literature analysis delivered in small groups face-to-face or via Teams in case of COVID restrictions; 1 x 1 hour session on academic integrity.

Teaching Method 2 - Laboratory Work
Description: Active participation in laboratory research in pursuit of the lab-project component of PHAR660, in the case of COVID restrictions “dry” experimental projects will be supervised by twice weekly one-to-one supervisor sessions within the 6-week research session.
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: 6 weeks x 3.5 days of project work plus 1 day of Lab Skills Unscheduled Directed Student Hours (time spent away from the timetabled sessions but directed by the teaching staff): 140

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Library dissertation not anonymously marked. Dissertation marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Oral presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Poster presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Laboratory project report not anonymously marked. Report marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Educational Aims
The aims of this module are: To provide an opportunity to extensively research a specific topic (or topics) To afford insights into contemporary scientific methods and debate To encourage the development of independent working and critical appraisal skills
Marketing Module Synopsis
Pharmacology ResearchProjects (PHAR660) is a 30 credit module that runs throughout both semesters in Year 3. The module is designed to provide students with experience in conducting research projects, poster presentations, oral presentations and in preparing project reports and dissertations.
Outline Syllabus
PHAR660 comprises two main components; an experimental research project and a library-based dissertation. SIn Semester 1, students will do the library project. In Semester 2, students will undertake the experimental-research project Students will be allocated a different supervisor for their experimental and library projects. All students will receive training in the use of Endnote software in week 1, Semester 1. All students will also attend a tutorial on academic integrity in week 1. Students will work on the library project from 9am to 5pm on Tues to Thurs each week during weeks 2 to 6 (inclusive) of Semester 1. Students are permitted to work on their library project at other times during those weeks, on the understanding that lectures and coursework take priority at other times.Students will give a 15 minute presentation (10-11 mins talk, 3-4 mins questions; 8-12 slides) using Microsoft PowerPoint. Presentations will be held over two or more sessions during week 10 of Semester 1 (Group B) or Semester 2 (Group A) in front of an audience of fellow students and academic staff (who will act as markers).Students will submit an electronic copy of their final library dissertation by the end of week 11 of Semester 1 . In semester 2 students will undertake 2-3 days of Lab Skills training in week 1 o Students will work on the lab project from 9am to 5pm on Tues to Thurs each week during weeks 2 to 7 (inclusive) of Semester 2 . Students are permitted to undertake lab work on one additional day (Mon or Fri) of those weeks, on the understanding that lectures take priority on additional days.. In the event of COVID restrictions limiting student access to the research laboratories contingency plans have been designed. If lab space is limited students will work in small groups, whereby each performs 1 – 2 weeks of laboratory work which will then be collated with the collective data of the group to form the final data set for analysis and the basis of their report. If no lab access is possible students will be assigned a dry experimental. These can take the form of computational, modelling, bioinformatic analysis or database analysis projects and will be managed by the supervisor in the same way as the lboratory projects. Students will produce and present an A0 poster in week 10 of Semester 2 . Posters will be presented in a group session and students will discuss their poster content with and answer related questions from academic staff (who will act as markers). In case of COVID restrictions this can be done via Teams. Students will submit an electronic copy of their final laboratory project report by the end of week 11 of Semester 2
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Tutorial Description: One to one supervision sessions, delivered via Teams or face-to face if COVID restrictions allow to discuss progress of lab projects, direction and content of library dissertation, plus other supporting face-to-face sessions. Attendance Recorded: No.
Notes: 6 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of lab projects; 5 x 1 hour sessions for supervision of library projects; 1 x 2 hour session on Endnote, delivered via synchronous, online Teams workshop; 1 x 1 hour session on scientific literature analysis delivered in small groups face-to-face or via Teams in case of COVID restrictions; 1 x 1 hour session on academic integrity.

Teaching Method 2 - Laboratory Work
Description: Active participation in laboratory research in pursuit of the lab-project component of PHAR660, in the case of COVID restrictions “dry” experimental projects will be supervised by twice weekly one-to-one supervisor sessions within the 6-week research session.
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: 6 weeks x 3.5 days of project work plus 1 day of Lab Skills Unscheduled Directed Student Hours (time spent away from the timetabled sessions but directed by the teaching staff): 140

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Library dissertation not anonymously marked. Dissertation marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Oral presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Poster presentation not anonymously marked. Marked by two independent academic staff. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Laboratory project report not anonymously marked. Report marked by supervisor and independent second marker. Supervisor additionally contributes a performance based mark. Marking descriptors and proformas can be found in the PHAR660 handbook available in Learning Resources section on PHAR660 VITAL page.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To undertake academic research in an efficient, safe and responsible manner
 LO2 ​To search, index and evaluate the scientific literature for the purposes of pharmacological study
 LO3 ​To plan, perform and record progress of studies that explore specific scientific questions and hypotheses
 LO4 ​To analyse and evaluate scientific data and information and draw informed conclusions
 LO5 ​To prepare written reports that effectively communicate scientific findings to the reader
 LO6 ​To prepare and deliver oral and poster presentations that effectively communicate scientific findings to the respective audience(s)
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Research management developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary/secondary/diverse sources, collecting &amp; using data, applying research methods, applying ethics
 S2 ​Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S3 ​​Problem solving skills
 S4 ​​Communication skills
